There's no one answer, but complexes are a turn-off

>Where do I go on a date?
Coffee is the ideal 1st date, but any of these work: food, drinks, ice cream, froyo, film, zoo, aquarium, museum, gallery, park

>I'm shy/afraid of <people/rejection>
>Where/how do I meet people for <friends/love/socialization>?
It takes time & effort. Leave your comfort zone. Find an activity you're passionate about.

>I'm a virgin with no friends, what do?
Get friends first

>I like someone, what do?
>How do I tell if someone likes me?
Ask him/her out; "signs" of attraction don't exist

>Something insignificant happened! What does it mean?
Can't say w/o detail; odds are you're overthinking it

>Someone made it clear he/she isn't interested. Do I have a chance?
No

>Do cold approaches work?
Not unless you have used car salesman levels of charisma

>Can I get out of the friendzone?
Not directly. All strats require friendship to decay to casual acquaintance, potential sexual attraction, & focus on him/her to die. You may need to date others to do this. The goal: approximate a normal pre-dating relationship and date normally. Success is very low, but higher than staying friends, but may take years.

posts.sub: Why is it impossible to find a girlfriend?
posts.com:
Correct me if I'm wrong but it comes down to three basic requirements: genetic attractiveness, superficial charm, and socioeconomic status. If you possess at least one of those three attributes, you have a chance of finding a girlfriend. You have to understand that women generally have an abundance of options available to them. They're not going to settle for anything less than they feel they deserve. Women have a biological imperative to choose the best physical specimen for their future offspring, even if they don't actively want children, it's hardwired into them. Similarly, they will also seek a man who can provide them with comfort and security. Pretty much every relationship can be boiled down to this. Sure, personality and compatibility are factors but all relationships start with a hook. My best friend is 6'6 and has chiseled features. He's never single for long. My other friend is short, chubby and has cerebral palsy BUT he has a well-paid job and shitton of savings. He finally found a girl to date him. I've also known plenty of guys who weren't particularly handsome but they were total arrogant scumbags. They always had girlfriends. I could go on and on...
So, if you're wondering why you're perennially single, this will be the reason. Unfortunately, most of these traits are out of your control. Genetics are predetermined, superficial charm is a character quirk, and status/money usually comes from a solid upbringing and the right opportunity.

posts.sub: I'm Terrified
posts.com:
Two nights ago I took a bunch of benzos (4mg ativan). Usually the stupidest thing I do on them is order overpriced food. I've never considered mixing alcohol with them. I used to be a drinker but have pretty much quit. But this time there was some leftover from Christmas and I was like "yeah lets have a sip and see what it does" and before I knew it I'd drunk everything I had; maybe up to 1/3 a bottle of bourbon plus a beer. Then I decided to drive.

I probably spent 50 minutes on the road on a Saturday night. It amazes me that I didn't have an accident nor get caught - let alone that I even made it to the car. I was really fucked up, or at least I think I was. I guess that's what the drugs do, but it's disturbing how little recollection I have.

I'm going to take steps to try prevent this from happening in the future. It's not the first time I've woken up from a bender terrified of what I had done. I'm terrified of what could have happened. But more than anything I'm terrified of how little control I had over my actions. And then if it happens again, if I get caught I'll be lucky. It could happen any time throughout my life, if I slip up and drink alcohol again or if I take any psychoactive drugs.

I've struggled on dating apps and part of it is for a long time I didn't have any self awareness about having shitty pictures. Grainy, not flattering angles, bad grooming, generic mirror selfies, etc. I know I am more attractive than my profiles have made me appear in the past.

Problem is I just don't have very many good photos of myself. I have a lot from when I was younger but I look more boyish and it doesn't reflect what I look like now. I have one set of professionally taken photos that look pretty good, but I don't want to just use those. It would be better to have some more variety. One option is I could pay to get more professional photos taken. Would it look unusual if I have only professional photos and no more natural looking photos of me doing things or being with friends? I guess the optimal profile would be a mix of both.

That brings me to the other problem. I don't really have any friends to take pictures of me. That would make things quite easy if I did. Perhaps this is symptomatic of a larger problem I need to solve before dating. It has just been difficult because I moved to a new city and I work from home. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28279427
You start by having a concrete vision of what you actually want to be in your head. Have that? Good. Now strip away the parts that are unreasonable or idealistic. Nobody is perfect, nobody is a novel like character stoic.

Then assess your own personality. How much of it is actually as bad as you think it is? Why change everything if there are good things about you to salvage and either accept or strengthen?

Now take what remains. The realistic, attainable, earnest improvements and traits you can adopt and work on from your ideal self, and the acceptable, workable parts of you that already make you you. Work on harmonizing those and becoming that person. Be who you are with an upward aim of being the best version of that actual self, not someone else.

Good luck

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28279427
>How do you, seriously, change the way you think and see the world, and the way you see yourself?
By gaining a wider perspective of life than the one you have right now. You can achieve this by going to therapy, being in an ungrateful job, doing activities you wouldn't do normally, walking around your city without listening to music or something else.

Everyone struggles at being confident with their own selves. I guess is an essential part of the human condition. I too feel weird in my own skin but typically the thing you admire in someone else are things that you value. So you think that if you had those traits you admire then you would be valued and esteemed. Would you like to change if more people vocally appreciated you for the way you are? Think about that. because it can turn out that the thing you seek is validation from others and the only way you think it can be achieved is to become someone admirable so you now make your wish and objective to change yourself in order to be accepted.

>How do I change my baseline? How to i reset?
You simply can't reset the person you are and thinking you can flip a switch to magically become the thing you want to be is just a manifestation of childish desire. You are basically thinking like a young boy who wants to be a superhero he is not so won't have to deal with the pain that the world inflicts on everyone.

You can indeed change your flaws and your defects that impede you from achieving the life you want. But to do that you must first accept yourself and realize that you are not at fault of how the world and your parents made yourself to be but that doesn't make you mess responsible to play with the hand that life dealt to you with the best strategy you can.

In summary. Go out there and see that there's a world outside your head. Talk to other people with other types of struggles and hardships, listen to how they perceive themselves.

Hello. 18yo here, skinny 4/10, I turned 18 in November so I’m a zoomer loser. I likely have AVPD, but no other disorders.

I feel completely empty when I think about the years I’ve wasted and I’ll continue to waste. I am utterly unable to connect with others, my mind going into fight/flight mode when people so much as look at me. This started as a tween and has only worsened. I go through the Instagram pages of old peers and just feel so numb at how they’ve at least experienced something in their youth, good or bad, while the most exciting thing for me was having a nap. I know that having friends and relationships (I don’t even want sex) is out of the question for me, but I still feel so miserable when I see people with them.

At least as a kid, I could be happy with cartoons and games. As an adult, I spend all of my time pacing and maladaptive daydreaming about people thinking I’m cool, or just having conversations in my head. If I could go back to immersing myself in fiction, I could be somewhat happy, but I can’t even do that anymore as thoughts of wanting validation are the only things on my mind. I go back and look at airdates of episodes of my favourite shows as a kid and feel so numb thinking that back then, at least I was a little happy with my shows and games. I have no hobbies, there’s nothing I really enjoy aside from daydreaming, and it’s fairly obvious but I have no friends; even amongst outcasts I don’t fit in and can’t find my voice.

I tried therapy when I was 15, but it was just going over my day and evaluating how I felt, which is stuff I could do by myself, and my job doesn’t pay enough now for a new one. I live in England, so no shotgun to the head for me. I’m too scared to do it any other way. I’m living in the past and know the future is bleak, I don’t think there’s a way out. I just want to go back to being a kid, I don’t want to grow old and I know that I’m rotting. How do I cope with not wanting to grow up?

I don't know how it is in the rest of the world, but here in Australia that's absolutely not the case. High schoolers coordinate universities and courses. I went to several different universities in several different courses for reasons, and everywhere I went I saw the same thing; on day 1, everyone has their group already, of people they already knew. The ones who DON'T don't want to be disturbed, or are... you know, 'those'. These days a significant percentage are also not English speakers, and I don't know how the universities swing that but it's clearly just to make money off them. Even in classes, the second that class ends, that very instant, everyone in the room disappears. They're out, they not there anymore. The vast majority of students are still living at home, too, so they don't hang around for parties or that shit, and they have social media to stay with their old friend groups from high school. They're NOT looking for anything and not interested in you. I spent an above average amount of time in university and I came out of it with a laundry list of failures. I'm a retard, but I'm not a totally autistic fuck; I'm not willing to put it down entirely to myself being an outlier hopeless case.

>>28282117
Ask yourself if you've sincerely tried everything you could do to make your life better.

Let me give you a scenario of something that happened to me a few years back that I learned from:

>Be me
>23-24
>Still living at home, working part-time at a retail job I haven't advanced at in 8 years.
>Born with birth defects. Nothing so severe that it can't be fixed, but I've put my life on hold until they can be fixed. Meaning no dating, no leaving for school.
>I'm told every time I go for an operation or a check-up that I should be excited I'm only "6 months away"
>Going in for one final try at an operation that's failed twice
>I have promised myself that if this operation fails, I am going to commit to committing suicide. I don't have a precise plan nor a note written, but I will take this as a cosmic sign to just go ahead and do it.
>It fails
You know what I felt? Relief. Suddenly I was committing to committing suicide and nothing mattered. I weirdly had unburdened myself from anything I was feeling upset or insecure about and for the first time in my life I felt free to do whatever I wanted.

That's how you should feel and try to feel before you commit to anything. Is there something you've always wanted to do or try? Do it, try it. Before you can't. Take a big swing before you quit.

>why do people say sex is overrated
Anyone that knows their shit and says this is speaking about life, typically in the context of romantic relationships.

No quantity or quality of sex is going to make people compatible, or fulfilled, in the long haul.
The novelty of even great sex loses its luster relatively quickly. A lot of people on here are too young and inexperienced to have a decent understanding of longevity.

It's difficult to convey something like this to someone with no reference point, so I'll try a metaphor:
>you like monster movies
>see trailer for new monster movie
>monster looks really cool
>go to movie
>movie is shit
>oh, cool, the monster
>then more shitty movie
>and more shitty movie
>cool monster
>shit movie
>shit movie
>cool monster don't even care anymore
>shit movie oh god when will this end
>shit movie still going
It's that, except you have to sit through the shit movie (for days, weeks, months, years, decades - 24/7) if you ever want to see the monster. There's no pausing, no fast forwarding, no rewinding... just you and the shit movie that happens to have a monster you think is cool. You can stop watching the movie any time you want, but you will never get to see the monster again. Eventually, you're not going to give a shit whether or not you see the monster as long as you don't have to put up with the rest of the movie.
That's what it's like in a relationship when sex is the only thing worthwhile in it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28280865
Sex is great, but it's not the be-all, end-all.

Incels here dramatically over-estimate how good it is. Physically, if you've ever jerked off, you already know what an orgasm feels like, the end physical result is the same in both cases. Most of the actual enjoyment and fulfillment of the act comes from doing something nice with someone you care about, the ego boost that someone let you have sex with them, bonus "being there" sensations (taste, smell, sound), and the thought that you can brag about it later to other guys.

That said, compared to all the things incels THINK sex will do, it's not that much to write home about. It's definitely not going to magically fix the other problems in their life, let alone solve all their problems. It's not going to fill any unfilled yawning holes in their heart, or magically give them friends if they don't have any, or make people in their life respect them if they don't, cure existing mental illnesses, or give them a new and substantially happier personality.

Put it another way: let's say you're an incel having a 3/10 life experience. In the alternative world where the follow happened
>we change nothing else about your life, except now we magically send you a girlfriend at any attractiveness level you plausibly could pull
>no work required, but she's a guaranteed 5/10 sexiness minimum if you couldn't do better
>she'll fuck you once or twice a week, hang out with you, has a reasonably okay personality, and can hold very basic mildly-past-normie-tier conversations about your interests, and more in-depth talks about her own.
The reason that sex is overrated is that even in this alternative world, as hard as it might be to believe, most of you STILL wouldn't rate your life experience higher than a low 4 to high 6, and like 50-85% of that boost would be coming from the fact that you now have someone to talk with and hang out with, NOT that you're fucking.

That's why people say sex is overrated.

posts.sub: Kinda feel like I'm being held back
posts.com:
I love my friends.

Honestly, I do. I'd drop everything I'm doing to help them, but I honestly don't feel like I fit in. I feel like I'm an after thought to most of that friend group. and for the one's I'm closer with, I care deeply for and have a close bond with but I feel like I'm being held back.

It's like we are standing on a steep cliff, a cliff that has a ledge on the other side. That ledge can be reached with a leap of faith. It's like we all are just standing there, looking down off the cliff, being freaked out of the jump, afraid of change, afraid of what's ahead. It feels like I'm the one standing there hyping everyone else up to jump. To take the leap, to see what that path ahead of us has, to want to take the chance of failure to move forward.

Yet I feel out of place, it's like my words fall upon deaf ears. Almost like the people I've surrounded myself with have become complacent. Ok with mediocrity, ok with the idea of staying where they are at or following the path everyone else has taken. Not the one that hasn't been explored.

But then again, I think to myself. Constantly. What if I take the leap first? Will they follow? How different am i really? Would I be frowned upon for doing so? And would I lose those that I was close with because I jumped? Or would they follow. Would I be despised for jumping without the people who walked with me? How would they react?

I'm not sure. And I'm scared of walking alone, those who have gone thus far by my side have been with me from the start. And I don't want to leave them behind. But what if they don't follow? Do I take the leap anyways? Or do I stay safe and stay in my pack.

I don't even know if I can make the leap myself. I've ran up to the edge plenty of times yet, I never jump. I want to jump, I feel like I should jump. But I'm held back by my mind. I'm afraid of who I'll leave behind, I don't know what lies ahead. I'm afraid of the unknown. And I'm lost.

I should probably journal this instead.

posts.sub: Overcoming severe lifelong social anxiety
posts.com:
I'm turning 26 in two weeks and I haven't been in a real relationship since high school, and besides that, I've barely made any friends that weren't over the internet and have only held a handful of jobs since highschool as well because my anxiety has evolved to being terrified of talking to people in person in public.

To preface, I've had ADHD and possibly aspergers since I was like 5. I once went 3 years in grade school without talking to a single soul in middle school. Yes, I talked to absolutely nobody once for 3 years besides family, a ton of kids suspected I was literally mute. I only ever got relationships (around 3-4 real girlfriends) in high school out of genuine fumbling into it out of luck and my first girlfriend thought my extreme quietness was pretty weird. At that time throughout my entire school life I was heavily heavily dosed on ADHD meds that made talking to people insanely hard so I just rarely talked to anyone except childhood friends I grew up with and people who just knew me my whole life. I'm utterly terrified of talking to strangers and have no idea how to hold a normal conversation that isn't autistically spazzing out. Even among new friends I vibe really well with I get insanely nervous and lose the ability to come up with conversation ideas moments in.

Despite this I somehow actually have a comically larger than you'd expect pool of friends-- but all of them know I'm super anxious. Ever since I got off the meds I slightly improved, but my social skills dramatically improve on the internet compared to real life. In real life I IMMEDIATELY start spilling spaghetti even among friends. Over Voice chat online, it's like a totally different person comes alive and my own family even thinks it's insane how much more confident I am.

I desperately want to be normal and also meet new people, make friends, and be an adult who can talk normally but I have no idea how when my real life anxiety is so overwhelming.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28281196
I'm a manager too. Do you have a team or are you realistically on your own?

If you've got a team, delegate the smaller, less important tasks. That'll take some of the pressure off you so you can prioritise the work that you need to do personally.

If you don't have a team, pick the quickest, easiest win and just get that done. Don't worry about the rest yet, the aim here is to just start ticking stuff off your list. It'll both reduce the mental load on you and give you something to show if the higher ups start getting in your shit. Once you've done one, do the next one.

It's also worth noting that a lot of the scary upper management stuff is probably in your head. Your immediate superiors know you're new and they won't be expecting you to solve all the worlds problems today.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28281322
I know the feeling bro. I'm the same sort of person, I fell into it in the same way and I often feel the way you do now.

Overthinking is a big problem for me as well. Break the list of stuff you need to do into chunks and work through them a bit at a time. You can do this.

Don't be afraid to ask for help on the things that you don't know about, even if you feel like it's stuff you should know. Just make sure to take notes because asking people the same questions twice might piss them off.

Management work uses a different skillset from the kinds of work non-managers use and it'll take some time and experience to really get a feel for what is expected of you. The people who put you in the role know this. Chances are pretty good that they had to go through it themselves.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28281459
>long have you been a manager and did it get better overtime in terms of stress?
11 years, and no, at least in my case. My current role is a lot higher profile with a lot more responsibility and a lot less direct subordinates than I had back when I started. All that adds up to more stress, but there's so many different factors outside of your list of shit to do that can contribute to your stress levels that it's impossible to say how you'll be affected.

I can say though that the longer I stayed in each of my roles, the less stressful each role became as I became more comfortable with it. It was only really when my role changed or expanded that stress really crept up again.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28281578
I will say though, that I've got a high pressure role in a fast moving industry. If that doesn't describe you, you'll probably get a feel for things and de-stress soon enough.

My main advice for managing stress over the longer term is to not let yourself get isolated in the workplace. Go to lunch with colleagues, have after-work drinks, all that boring office social stuff. It will pay off.

I know you probably don't want to be told to wait it out, or to think things over; I definitely didn't, but imo it can be helpful to just have a crush on someone without pursuing it while you're trying to recuperate. I think when I broke up with her I had been in a relationship for so long I forgot the ups of being single.

At the end of the day it's your life, don't let some random person on the internet push you one way or another. It's a tough situation to be in, and it takes time to see the flipside of things, but you will get there, whether you're running or crawling.

>>28279801
From what Ive seen you either become a civil or criminal attorney. There is less crossover than you’d guess. Civil practice focuses heavily on motion practice and general faggotry. Criminal practice is much more focused on having good relations with the prosecutors. You will get shit deals if you act like an asshole civil attorney in criminal court.

A middle road that I would suggest is to become a private criminal defense attorney. Charge a ton and help people. Its a ton of fun. The public defender’s office is generally for people who have given up on life or are diehards, no crimes are ever committed types.

If you cant get a summer job with a judge or big law firm, you can of course apply to the PD’s office or DA’s office. I recommend working for a private investigator who is death penalty certified. You will learn and build connections there over being one of a zillion random interns at the DA/PD’s office.

For preparation:
Civil - learn how to write motions well. Legal writing is not like normal bullshit college writing. Stick to IRAC. You also have to have balls of steel, hate the world, love shit flinging, and have top tier negotiating skills.

Criminal -
Take the classes. Its a lot about personal diplomacy, dont be an outright asshole or pushover. You will work with the same DAs for decades. Do not try criminal defense without a mentor attorney

Both - Litigation. Take trial ad and do mock trial. If you can fuck in court, you will be fine where ever. Appellate practice also has decent overlap.

Law school is a bitch. The bar is a huge bitch. You will likely do something completely different from what you are expecting by the end of it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Ok first let's define some things so we're on the same page and realistic expectations abound.

Smarter =\= more intelligent.

Intelligence is the measure of potential capacity for thought & reason. It is fixed in the womb, so it can never be increased.

Smarter is the act of learning things to your full capacity.

You can become smarter, you can't become more intelligent. Think of intelligence as the hard limit to how smart you can ever be, and your capacity to become smarter.

Stupid is the lacking of intelligence leading to slower or more difficulty learning. This also can't be changed.

Now that's out of the way, the solution to becoming smarter should be obvious. One must ACT to LEARN and EXPERIENCE new things, then EVALUATE those things. One must seek CREDIBLE sources of information, such as institutions of learning, curated encyclopaedias, scientific papers, etc. One should PRACTICE those things with which one is not wholly familiar or proficient, whilst understanding ones own limitations and creating mental/behavioural strategies to maximise potential.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>28278465
Smarter at WHAT, in particular?

You get smarter at certain processes, tasks, or ways of thinking. There is no getting "smarter" in some kind of universal cross-subject improvement. To the extent that people say you do, it's improvement at some range of these more hyper-focused areas.

If your goal is to get smarter at something you're stupid at, you ideally want to learn as fast as possible. Know that the universal process of learning is at its core a biological one,
>An ability in organisms to use past experiences to make informed decisions for a particular situation
And as the definition would suggest, having access to more prior experiences, both personal and external, better informative prior experiences, or more applicable past experience, will basically always accelerate and improve your learning process.

I mean otherwise it just seems like your time, your work, will be wasted when you die. Oddly enough though, i have very little interest in actual doing STEM for the rest of my life. I already have quite a bit of experience, but i have a hard time justifying spending my entire life on it. I mean will anything i achieve in computer science do anything to further humanity? Doubt it. I'll make some programs and whatnot which wont matter in ~100 years from now.

I know you shouldn't feel like you *have* to dedicate yourself to what is best for humanity, and most people would say you should just do what you want to do, which i agree with, but personally i do want to dedicate myself to what is best, rather than what i enjoy the most. So if i honestly cant justify computer science being a worth while thing to dedicate myself to, then im just going to bite the bullet and go into STEM.

Just wondering /hoping if one of you guys could come up wtih any logical reason whatsoever that going into computer science, isn't a total waste of life that im otherwise okay with spending more productively.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I can't really give you an answer because it's reliant upon what you personally want. If you want to simply enjoy life, don't do it. If you want to potentially help with the advancement of humanity, then go ahead and do it. The chances you alone will make any difference is quite small and even if we look at it from a perspective of long term gains, you may not see the fruits of your labor and may potentially die unfulfilled.
You only have one life, you choose what you want to do with it, but choose wisely. I personally would not waste it on something I did not enjoy, however this doesn't indicate I prefer the opposite extreme of total hedonism.

posts.sub: How to establish self-love?
posts.com:
(sorry for this blog post, but I promise there is a question at the end. skip to the end if you want.)

I just had an epiphany as a 24 year old guy. I wondered why I was doing so bad in the dating world, but I realized it was mostly do to inner struggles, namely:

>I lack self-confidence and I am insecure in my self
>I set unrealistic expectations for my life, and good things look shitty by comparison
>I lack respect for my basic needs (sleep as a huge example) and don't set boundaries for myself

I realized that these 3 things are why I am so needy for girl and pour so much expectations into strangers instead of loving myself. But now I must work to fix my damaged psychology. I hate myself so much that I constantly leak negative energy. I plague myself with dark thoughts and cause my own suffering by comparing myself to a mythological "Chad" standard that I will never match. I am socially sort of stunted and wasn't a popular kid, and I punish myself everyday for it. Even though I am not an incel, somehow my brain has become just as jaded and bitter as if I was one.

This is my plan to fix myself, and I would like feedback on how to achieve the following:

>Re-define my self worth
How do I shift how I think of myself? Everyday I see a failure in the mirror even though I have a good job and established hobbies.
>stop looking for validation from strangers and foster current and new friendships
How do I best go about this? This seems to be half mindset change, half putting myself out there without expectation of finding a gf/one night stand.
>Make sure I am listening well to what my body wants. too often I accommodate other people too much.
This is rather simple, I need to learn a bit of selfishness here. For instance dramatically altering my schedule to meet some random girl I just matched with on a dating app.

Since everyone in the thread is a sperg I'll throw my hat in the ring:

I dated plenty for around a decade before settling down with who I decided to marry last year as far as qualifications. We met on OKcupid.

For your question: the time isn't important as long as it feels right and you are into each other. Even if you decided to have sex on the first date, if you were both really into each other and you hit it off right off the bat there's nothing wrong with that. Whatever you are comfortable with is what you should do. There aren't any rules.

Me and my wife had sex on our third date and that was about 6 years ago. Our first couple dates were perfect, we talked for hours and it felt like I was hanging with an old friend.

For those trashing online dating: it's all about how you use the tools. If you list good info, have substantive conversations on dates, and everything feels right then there's nothing different going that route vs. meeting someone irl. If anything you can go out of your way to only seek people that share your interests and principles online if you make sure to ask some of those questions on the date or list that info on your profile. Dating still sucked before the internet, those saying it's way worse now are children that never experienced it before, or it's old people coping because no one wants their washed up wrinkly ass. If anything hookups are worse online, because only the top men get that sort of attention. But if you want to date there are tons of women and men that are looking for a proper relationship.

posts.com:
>>28276460
It's less about a set pack of characteristics and mannerisms you need to emulate, and more about developing confidence and self-assurance in who you are and what you're capable of. That attitude will be what draws people, because, if you know who you are, and have put effort into loving yourself and making peace with your shortcomings, that is what confidence is. Have the kind of fun that you enjoy having, be open to new experiences, be willing to share yourself with others, find belief that your thoughts, feelings, and perspectives are as valid and worthwhile as other's, and be willing to engage with people and experiences that challenge all of that anyways. Don't take things too seriously, just be a solid dude and look for other solid people who might not exactly be like you, but who can appreciate you anyways. Don't worry about impressing the crowd, let your actions speak for you, do less telling and do more showing. You don't need to be anyone but yourself, you just have to learn to accept and love who that is, and not be afraid to show it. Even if you're a fat, dorky weirdo, a confident, self-assured fat, dorky, weirdo can be seen as charismatic.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28276527
You're alright buddy. One skill you may be lacking in, can't say from a brief exchange like this, is the ability to engage with ideas that aren't up your alley. Doesn't matter if the other person isn't necessarily knowledgeable or interested in what you are, or vice-versa, you just have to be able to show interest, ask questions, and relate your own ideas and experiences to it, as well as being willing to show your own side of it. You also don't need to appeal to everyone, or have good conversational chemistry with everyone, it's the difference between an excellent movie that appeals to a niche audience, and an okay movie that appeals to the majority. One isn't necessarily "better" than the other, but with mass-appeal comes some loss of content or focus that you don't have to pursue. You just have to find people who can relate to you, or at least appreciate what you have to offer in a conversation. You can have both, too, no reason why you can't save the more niche interests for those who can appreciate them, while still learning to keep an exchange up with more generally relatable topics. Just show interst, know your audience, share yourself, and be known as a good, solid dude even if others can't understand. It's less complex or skill-based than you think. You're entertaining in your own way, to a certain kind of person, and that's all you need, you just gotta let that guy out and do his own thing. If there are any substances or practices that you know allow you to ignore your inhibitions, try using them to practice, or try mushrooms and gain peace with everything.
